Design Note: HTML Style Sheets¶

Architecture and Design

Problem¶

Consistent, recognizable brand identity is essential to successful software use.

Forces¶

There are, however, two competing approaches to brand identity.

  1. Make Tiger blend in with a customer’s existing web applications, providing a largely eamless experience.
  2. Provide Tiger with a unique identity.

Consistent with the second approach, a general color scheme, page layout and icon style are essential.

Solution¶

See the following URLs for candidate color schemes:

  • http://www.wellstyled.com/tools/colorscheme2/index-en.html?triad;38;0;60;0.5;1;-1;-1;1;-0.7;0.25;1;-1;-1;1;-0.7;0.25;1;0.5;1;-1;-1;1;-0.7;0.25;1;0.5;1;-1;-1;1;-0.7;0.25;1;0.5;1;1
  • http://www.wellstyled.com/tools/colorscheme2/index-en.html?triad;38;0;60;0.5;1;1;1;1;0.7;0.25;1;1;1;1;0.7;0.25;1;0.5;1;1;1;1;0.7;0.25;1;0.5;1;1;1;1;0.7;0.25;1;0.5;1;1

This is a “triad” color scheme using a very bright web-save orange (Tigers, get it?) as the highlight color.

(See http://fohn.net/tiger-pictures-facts/ for some pictures of tigers.)

Consequences¶

All pages must be built with flexible templates to permit customer-specific look and feel to replace Tiger native look and feel.
